facts.text: Appeal by special leave granted by Supreme Court on 3rd September 1954

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court by its Order dated the 3rd September, 1954 from the Judgment

facts.text: High Court judgment and order dated 15th June 1954 in Criminal Appeal No. 287 of 1954

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th June 1954 of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab at Simla in Criminal

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge judgment dated 14th April 1954 in Session Case No. 4 of 1954

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 287 of 1954 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 14th April 1954 of the Court of Additional Sessions Judge

facts.text: Sadhu Ram killed on 5th November 1953 at about 6:45 PM at shop of Vas Dev PW 2

anchor.surface_text: On the facts alleged by the prosecution there can be no doubt that Sadhu Ram was killed on the 5th of November, 1953, at about 6-45 P.m.

facts.text: Appellant along with others assaulted Sadhu Ram

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the appellant along with others assaulted Sadhu Ram. The appellant was armed with a takwa.

facts.text: Appellant armed with a takwa during assault

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was armed with a takwa. Numerous injuries were found on the person of Sadhu Ram.

facts.text: Numerous injuries found on Sadhu Ram

anchor.surface_text: Numerous injuries were found on the person of Sadhu Ram. According to the doctor, who held the postmortem examination,

facts.text: Injuries 1,3,4 due to heavy sharp edged weapon, could be caused by takwa per doctor

anchor.surface_text: According to the doctor, who held the postmortem examination, injuries 1, 3 and 4 were due to a heavy sharp edged weapon and could be caused by a takwa.

facts.text: Prosecution denied deceased assaulted by any other person with takwa

anchor.surface_text: It was denied by the prosecution that the deceased was assaulted by any other person with a takwa.

facts.text: Injuries 1,3,4 individually or collectively enough to cause death per medical evidence

anchor.surface_text: According to the Medical evidence, injuries 1, 3 and 4 individually, as well as collectively, were enough to cause death in the ordinary course of nature.

facts.text: Sessions Court charged appellant and others u/s 148 and 302/149 IPC

anchor.surface_text: In the Court of Sessions the appellant along with others was charged under section 148 and section 302, read with section 149 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge held rioting not proved, convicted appellant and three others u/s 302/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, however, held, that the charge of rioting was not proved. He, accordingly found the appellant and three others guilty under section 302 read with section 34

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the other three accused

anchor.surface_text: He acquitted the other three accussed There was an appeal by three convicted persons to the High Court

facts.text: High Court convicted appellant alone u/s 302 IPC, confirmed death sentence

anchor.surface_text: and the high court convicted the appellant alone under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code, confirming the sentence of death but altered the conviction

facts.text: High Court altered conviction of other accused from 302/34 to 323 IPC

anchor.surface_text: confirming the sentence of death but altered the conviction of the other accused from section 302/34 to section 323, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court held section 34 IPC did not apply

anchor.surface_text: it held that the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did not apply.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by IMAM J. on January 25, 1955

anchor.surface_text: 1955. January 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-This appeal by Nanak Chand

facts.text: Appellant convicted by High Court u/s 302 IPC and sentenced to death by Additional Sessions Judge confirmed

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by Nanak Chand by special leave against the judgment of the Punjab High Court. The appellant was convicted by the High Court under section 302
under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code and the sentence of death passed on him by the Additional Sessions Judge

concepts.interpretation: Substantive offence requiring specific charge distinct from constructive liability under s149.

issues.text: whether the appellant could legally be convicted for murder and sentenced under section 302, Indian Penal Code when he was not charged with that offence

anchor.surface_text: The principal question of law to be considered is as to whether the appellant could legally be convicted for murder and sentenced under section 302, Indian Penal Code when he was not charged with that offence.

issues.text: whether this section [section 149 of the Indian Penal Code] creates a specific offence

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to examine the provisions of section 149 of the Indian Penal Code and consider as to whether this section creates a specific offence.

issues.text: whether section 149 of the Indian Penal Code creates a specific offence and it is a separate offence from the offence of murder punishable under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that as the appellant had been acquitted of the charge of rioting and the offence under section 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code, he could not be convicted for the substantive offence of murder under section 302, Indian Penal Code, without a charge having been framed against him under that section.

issues.text: whether the provisions of sections 236, 237 and 238 of the Code of Criminal Procedure did apply to the facts and circumstances of the present case

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of sections 236, 237 and 238 of the Code of Criminal Procedure did not apply to the facts and circumstances of the present case.

issues.text: whether section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did apply

anchor.surface_text: it held that the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did not apply.

issues.text: whether under the provisions of section 236 and section 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure a person could be convicted of an offence which he is shown to have committed although he was not charged with it

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by the Prosecution that under the provisions of section 236 and section 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure a person could be convicted of an offence which he is shown to have committed although he was not charged with it.

issues.text: whether a conviction under section 302 read with section 149 could be converted into a conviction under section 302/34 or section 302

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that in view of the decision of this Court in Karnail Singh and another v. State of Punjab a conviction under section 302, read with section 149, could be converted into a conviction under section 302/34 which the trial Court did.

issues.text: whether the non-framing of a charge under section 302 has resulted in a failure of justice or whether the appellant was misled in his defence

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the provisions of section 535 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Reference was also made to the provisions of section 537 of that Code. Section 535 does permit a court of appeal or revision to set aside the finding or sentence if in its opinion the non-framing of a charge has resulted in a failure of justice.

arguments.claim: S149 creates specific offence

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to examine the provisions of section 149 of the Indian Penal Code and consider as to whether this section creates a specific offence.

arguments.claim: S149 distinct from s34: no common intention required

anchor.surface_text: There is a clear distinction between the provisions of sections 34 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code and the two sections are not to be confused. The principal element in section 34...

arguments.claim: Lord Sumner's observations in Barendra Kumar Ghosh support s149 as specific offence

anchor.surface_text: In Barendra Kumar Ghosh v. Emperor Lord Sumner dealt with the argument that if section 34... section 149 is certainly not otiose, for in any case it created a specific offence.

arguments.qualifiers: observations of a Judge of such eminence must carry weight

arguments.claim: Calcutta HC decisions correct: cannot convict substantive without charge if acquitted 149

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant certain decisions of the Calcutta High Court were relied upon... These decisions support the contention that it will be illegal to convict an accused of the substantive offence under a section without a charge being framed if he was acquitted of the offence under that section read with section 149

arguments.claim: Madras Full Bench view incorrect as predates PC decision

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution relied upon a decision of the Full Bench of the Madras High Court... The Madras High Court, therefore, did not have before it the decision of the Privy Council.

arguments.claim: S233 CrPC requires separate charge for s149 offence

anchor.surface_text: section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which provides that for every distinct offence of which any person is accused there shall be a separate charge.

arguments.claim: Ss236,237 CrPC inapplicable: no doubt as to offence

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of section 236 can apply only in cases where there is no doubt about the facts... In the present case there is no doubt about the facts... There was no room for the application of section 236

arguments.claim: Non-framing of s302 charge is illegality causing failure of justice; ss535,537 inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, however, there is no question of any error... we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and not an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant misled; would have cross-examined differently on injuries, witnesses

arguments.claim: Appellant prejudiced: would have focused defence on medical evidence, witnesses re takwa

holdings.text: A person charged with an offence read with section 149 cannot be convicted of the substantive offence without a specific charge being framed as required by section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: After an examination of the cases referred to on behalf of the appellant and the prosecution we are of the opinion that the view taken by the Calcutta High Court is the correct view namely, that a person charged with an offence read with section 149 cannot be convicted of the substantive offence without a specific charge being framed as required by section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined statutory text of s149, distinguished from s34, followed Calcutta HC precedents over Madras FB, applied s233 CrPC requiring separate charge for distinct offence.

holdings.text: Section 149 of the Indian Penal Code creates a specific offence.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by reference to section 40 of the Indian Penal Code that section 149 cannot be regarded as creating an offence because it does not itself provide for a punishment. Section 149 creates an offence but the punishment must depend on the offence of which the offender is by that section made guilty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter VIII context, postulates guilt for offence committed by member; examples s150, s471, s193, s195; punishment from the offence made guilty of.

holdings.text: Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code is merely explanatory and does not create any specific offence.

anchor.surface_text: This section is merely explanatory. Several persons must be actuated by a common intention and when in furtherance of that common intention a criminal act is done by them, each of them is liable for that act as if the act had been done by him alone. This section does not create any specific offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires common intention; distinguished from s149 which needs no common intention, only membership; cited Lord Sumner in Barendra Kumar Ghosh.

holdings.text: There is a clear distinction between the provisions of sections 34 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code and the two sections are not to be confused.

anchor.surface_text: There is a clear distinction between the provisions of sections 34 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code and the two sections are not to be confused. The principal element in section 34 of the Indian Penal Code is the common intention to commit a crime.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S34 needs common intention and participation; s149 liability via membership in unlawful assembly without intention or act.

holdings.text: The provisions of sections 236 and 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure did not apply to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of section 236 can apply only in cases where there is no doubt about the facts which can be proved but a doubt arises as to which of several offences have been committed on the proved facts... There was no room for the application of section 236 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No doubt about facts or offence committed; ss236-237 only where doubt which offence on proved facts.

holdings.text: There was an illegality and not an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and not an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of charge under s302 is illegality, not error/omission/irregularity; ss535/537 cure irregularities without failure of justice only.

holdings.text: The appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, however, for a moment that there was merely an irregularity... we are satisfied that... the irregularity is not curable because the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would have cross-examined doctor on incised injuries, witnesses on takwa; defence focused on 302/149 not individual murder.

anchor.surface_text: This section is merely explanatory. This section does not create any specific offence.
